Highly porous monolith/TiO2 supported Cu, Cu-Ni, Ru, and Pt catalysts in methanol steam reforming process for H2 generation Pooya Tahay a Yasin Khani a Mohammad Jabari a Farzad Bahadoran b ⁎ Nasser Safari a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, 1983963113 Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Shahid Beheshti University Evin Tehran 1983963113 Iran b Gas Research Division, Research Institute of Petroleum Industry, West Blvd. of Azadi Sport complex, 1485733111, Tehran, Iran Gas Research Division Research Institute of Petroleum Industry West Blvd. of Azadi Sport complex Tehran 1485733111 Iran ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Fabrication of a micro/nano combined structure as support in methanol steam reforming process with high conversion and selectivity. A comprehensive investigation on the steam reforming of methanol (SRM) process using a microstructure monolith in conjunction with a synthesized nanostructure of TiO2 is presented. The surface of the designed monolith/TiO2 structure was coated with copper, copper/nickel, ruthenium, and platinum as the catalyst. The prepared catalysts were then characterized with FE-SEM, AFM, BET surface area measurement, FT-IR, far-infrared, temperature programmed reduction (TPR), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The obtained results show that in this process, the designed Monolith/TiO2 structure has a remarkable impact on methanol conversion (99%) and carbon monoxide selectivity (5%). These results are interpreted by the high surface area and superb mass transfer in this micro/nano engineered structure. These results also indicated that the catalyst activity and dispersion are influenced by the metal-support interaction, which is more pronounced in the TiO2 supports. The ruthenium catalyst presented the highest conversion and selectivity for this process. However, the economically viable property of the Cu-Ni catalyst supposes it as an alternative for the noble ruthenium catalyst. Keywords Steam reforming of methanol Heterogeneous catalysis Titanium oxide Monolith 1 Introduction The environmental pollution as a result of fossil fuels is a global major concern. It is essential to find and replace these sources of energy with novel and green sources. Producing energy with fuel cells is one of the most promising procedures to make green energy [1,2]. Although preparing energy with these cells is environmentally friendly, this preparation requires hydrogen as a fuel [3]. Hydrogen is an explosive gas, and its storage and transportation have proven to be dangerous. In-situ preparation of the hydrogen is one of the approaches that can be used to solve the mentioned storage and transportation problems. With this intention, steam reforming of methanol (SRM) is the preferred method for in-situ hydrogen production [4]. An advantage of the SRM method is that it has the highest efficiency to hydrogen production compared to other methods [5]. Furthermore, by having only one carbon in the methanol structure, the process temperature is lower in comparison with other reforming processes such as the ethanol reforming process (400 °C) [6]. This is due to the lack of the strong CC bond in methanol. The methanol steam reforming reaction can be considered as follows: (1) CH3OH + H2O ↔ CO2 + 3H2 (2) CH3OH ↔ CO + 2H2 (3) CO + H2O ↔ CO2 + H2 The product mixture consists of hydrogen, carbon dioxide and small amounts of carbon monoxide along with unreacted water and methanol. Since the formed hydrogen is to be used in fuel cells, carbon monoxide formation must obviously be negligible, as carbon monoxide can deactivate the anode in low temperature fuel cells [7]. Therefore, the property and selectivity of the catalyst in the SRM process must be improved in order to obtain a desirable fuel cell feed. Generally, methanol reforming catalysts can be summarized in two different classes: a) copper based class [8,9] and b) group 8–10 metal based class [10,11] catalysts. The copper-based catalysts are the conventional catalysts used in this process due to their higher activity. However, these catalysts have pyrophoric characteristics and are deactivated by thermal sintering. In comparison with the copper based catalysts, group 8–10 metal catalysts have been introduced as stable and selective catalysts with lower methanol conversion [11]. Many strategies have achieved to improve the catalyst stability and activity in chemical process. Micro-engineering of reactors is one of these strategies, [12] which decreases the equipment dimensions, sizes, weights, and increases mass transfer properties. Monolithic structures are micro-engineered reactors, which consists of many parallel channels separated by thin walls. These structures are noble alternatives for the usually fixed bed reactors. Traditional fixed bed reactors have many disadvantages, which are attributed to the inappropriate distribution of current flow, mass transport resistance, and pressure drop problems [13]. For instance, 90% of dispersed catalyst is not used in these reactors because of the unsuitable mass transfer. Monolith reactors, however, overcome the above difficulties by losing the pressure drop due to their open front structure and connected channels. Mass transfer is appropriate in these systems [14] and efficiency is raised because of the appropriate contact of the reactants and catalyst [15,16]. Change of catalyst support can alter the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst and is another strategy to improve the stability and activity of the catalyst [11,17–20]. The catalyst supports must have acceptable physical stability due to the harsh environment of the reforming reactions. The support should also present suitable physical properties such as high surface area, porosity, and pore size in order to increase the loading capacity of the support and accessibility of the catalyst on itself. Alumina is a common support for catalyst in the SRM reaction, while both coke formation [21] and catalyst aggregation [22] are appreciated disadvantages in this support. These two effects have an undesirable impact on the activity of the catalyst by decreasing the catalyst active site. Consequently, in order to achieve a catalyst with high stability, activity, and endurance against coke formation, modification of alumina or design of new supports are in progress [23]. T i O 2 is a low cost, nontoxic, thermal, and chemically stable metal oxide using in many catalytic processes [24,25]. In addition, by changing the particle sizes and morphology of T i O 2 nanoparticles, one is able to fine-tune the surface area [26,27], pores size, and pores volume [28–30] of the T i O 2 support. In the past two decades, significant efforts have been devoted to the synthesis of T i O 2 support with such properties, due to its importance in many fields of science such as material and energy science [31–34]. For example, Barbe et al. [35] found a method for the preparation of T i O 2 nanoparticles film with high porosity and surface area, which was used in the solar cells modules. These properties play important roles in the steam reforming process both by increasing the metals active area and raising the substances diffusion in the catalyst support [36–38]. Kuila et al. [39] used a synthesized T i O 2 support for reforming methanol in a fixed-bed reactor. They found that due to the large surface area of the support, the degree of distribution, and activity of immobilized catalyst was raised. Alternatively, T i O 2 has shown temperature dependent interaction with metals (especially a strong metal-support interaction is reported with the noble metals) [40,41]. As a result, by changing the temperature one is able to control the catalyst properties [42] when T i O 2 is used as the catalyst support. For instance, the chemisorption of hydrogen and carbon monoxide on the surface of the metal catalyst can be controlled with this interaction [43,44]. Nichele et al. [45] found that the metal-support interaction in the nickel- T i O 2 catalyst plays a crucial role in the steam reforming reactions. Another advantage of the metal support interaction is the prevention of metal particles aggregation at the SRM reaction temperature. This aggregation affectedly reduces the catalyst activity by diminishing the catalyst surface area. In spite of the remarkable advantages of conjunct monolith structure with T i O 2 nanoparticle film as catalyst support in the methanol reforming process, no systematic studies have reported on this reaction by monolith/ T i O 2 support. For this reason, four different metal catalysts, including Cu, Cu-Ni, Pt, and Ru were deposited on the surface of monolith/ T i O 2 supports, which were used as catalysts in the SRM reaction. In order to provide a comprehensive understanding of catalysts activities and their relations to the structure of the prepared support advanced characterization methods such as FESEM, AFM, XRD, BET, FT-IR, TPR, and GC were performed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All solvents, titanium isopropoxide (TIP), α-terpinol, acetic acid, nitric acid, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ru(N = O) (NO3)3 and H2PtCl6·6H2O were purchased from Merck and used without further purification. Ethyl cellulose (5–15 mPas at 5% in toluene: ethanol 80:20) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. Ultra-Sonication (Sonics VC-750) and centrifugation (Sigma 3–18 ks) were performed with the indicated instruments. The H 2 P t ( O H ) 6 was synthesized with a previously reported method [46]. The monoliths used in this work were extruded cordierite with a square-channeled shape (400 cells/in.2) from Corning Company. X-ray analyses were conducted by XRD to identify the crystal structure using a model INEL EQUINOX 3000 X–ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) in the 2θ range of 5°–110°. The surface area, pore volume and pore diameters were estimated with the BET (Brunauer-Emmett Teller) method from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The data were obtained at −196 °C on a constant–volume adsorption apparatus (Micromeritics TriStar II 3020). Prior to the adsorption-desorption measurements, all samples were degassed at 200 °C in N2 flow for 3 h. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the catalysts were recorded using a Micromeritics TPR/TPD 2900 unit which employs a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). FE-SEM analysis was carried out to determine morphology and particle size using a field emission electronic microscope (FESEM), ZEISS, SIGMA Series. Atomic force microscope (AFM) was performed in a DPN 5000, working in the non-contact mode with standard silicon tips. All samples had been washed and cleaned by DI water before AFM images were taken. FT-IR and far infrared spectroscopy were performed by a Thermo Nicolet Nexus 870 FTIR ESP FT-IR Spectrometer. The viscosity was measured by Viscometer Fungilab model Alpha at 1 rpm. The catalyst stability test was performed with ultrasonic (Bandelin type DK 255 P) in ethanol for 15 min. 2.2 T i O 2 Nanoparticles and slurry preparation T i O 2 nanoparticles were synthesized by using a previously reported method [47]. 30 g of TIP was mixed with 6.3 g acetic acid for 10 min. The precursor was transferred into a solution of 150 ml water and 2.1 ml nitric acid while it was strongly stirred. After 30 min, the temperature was slowly increased to 80 °C and refluxed for 4 h. The solution was poured into a 250 ml autoclave and was heated at 200 °C for 12 h. After cooling, 1.5 ml nitric acid was added to the dispersing of the agglomerated T i O 2 nanoparticles. After sonication, the resultant colloidal solution was dried at 85 °C for 10 h. T i O 2 slurry was prepared using a modified method which has previously been reported [47]. 3 g of the synthesized T i O 2 was mixed with 3 ml of water and was grounded in a porcelain mortar. After 10 min of mixing, 30 ml methanol was slowly added into the mixture. This mixture was transferred to a beaker with 80 ml of methanol and sonicated for 15 min. 12 g of α-terpinol was added to the mixture and further sonicated for 15 min. In the next step, a 10% solution of ethyl cellulose in ethanol was added to the previous blend and the resulted mixture was sonicated for 15 min. Finally, the mixture was concentrated with a rotary evaporator to the most appropriate viscosity (320–370 cP) for wash coating. 2.3 Preparation of monolith/ T i O 2 /metal catalyst The procedure for the preparation of Monolith/ T i O 2 /metal catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The first step is the preparation of the monolith/ T i O 2 support by injection of T i O 2 slurry into the monolith channels, then removing the excess slurry by passing air through the monolith channels. After that, the prepared structure was dried for 15 min at 100 °C. Finally, the resulted structure was heated in a furnace at 450 °C for 15 min and 500 °C for another 15 min. The second step is the preparation of the catalyst by wet impregnation of the support in the 1 M solution of different metal salts (including copper nitrate, chloroplatinic acid, copper nitrate/nickel nitrate, and ruthenium acetate). After removing the monoliths from the corresponding metal nitrate solutions, they were dried in a microwave oven at 200 W for 10 min and calcined in air at 300 °C for 2 h (except H 2 P t C l 6 which calcined at 400 °C). 2.4 Reactor test Fig. S1. shows the performance evaluation system for monolith/TiO2/metal (metal: Cu, Cu-Ni, Pt, Ru) catalysts in methanol reforming reaction. The system is composed of feed stream mass flow control, reactor set, and gas analysis parts. Brooks 5850 E series flow controllers (MFC) have been used in the system. In this process, the outlet current from the reactor is sent to a condenser in which the temperature is reduced to 0 °C to separate the steam and unreacted methanol from the product. Ultimately, the methanol conversion and product selectivity are calculated using an online gas chromatography (Varian 3800 RGA equipped with TCD and FID) by the following equation [48,49]: (4) Convesion = ( CH 3 O H in - CH 3 O H out CH 3 O H in ) × 100 (5) CO Selectivity = CO ( C O 2 + CO + C H 4 ) × 100 (6) H 2 Selectivity = H 2 ( H 2 + 2 C H 4 ) × 100 he steam reforming of methanol reaction was carried out using each of monolith/TiO2/metal catalysts in the temperature range of 150–300 °C and with feed flow rate of weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) 1.8 h−1 at atmospheric pressure in a monolith reactor with a quartz cover (WHSV = weight hourly of feed/total weight of catalyst and monolith). Honeycombed monoliths with 0.7 × 0.7 × 3 cm dimensions were placed in the middle part of the furnace inside the quartz reactor. The temperature inside the quartz reactor was monitored using a thermocouple on the monolith bed exit. All gases used were 99.99% purity. The catalyst was pre-activated in-situ at 350 °C for 2 h under 10% H2/N2 environment. The feed mixture for methanol reforming was composed of N2/H2O/CH3OH at a ratio of 1:2:1, with nitrogen gas used as a diluent. The above process for the fixed bed rector was carried out under atmospheric pressure in a flow system equipped with a 6 mm ID quartz reactor and an electrically heating furnace. The catalyst activation and feed mixture for the reforming was the same as the monolithic reactor. The loaded catalyst was diluted with crushed quartz glasses (50–70 mesh size) in a catalyst/quartz volume ratio of 2:1 to increase the inter particle porosity and decrease the pressure drop across the reactor. 3 Results and discussion AFM and FESEM images of the synthesized T i O 2 nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 2 , displaying the morphology of the calcined T i O 2 nanoparticles at 500 °C. According to these images, the average size of the synthesized T i O 2 particles is about 30 nm (also see supporting information Figs. S2–5). These images indicate that the T i O 2 nanoparticles are finely dispersed in the prepared slurry and no aggregated or agglomerated particles are observed. The stability of T i O 2 against aggregation was achieved by the acetic acid additive in the hydrothermal process [35,50]. In the same way, using the α-terpinol/ethyl cellulose mixture completely prevented the agglomeration of the particles in the slurry. Moreover, the T i O 2 layer treatment at 500 °C (for 15 min) improved the necks between the T i O 2 particles, which increased the particles conjunction. This conjunction depends on particle size and temperature [51] and increases the T i O 2 layer stability under SRM reaction. Cracking resistance of the T i O 2 layer is another important mechanical property of this layer [52], which makes an effective adherence between the T i O 2 layer and the monolith surface.[53,54] This appropriate adherence is one of the main factors that affects the catalyst stability, mainly because of making a stable structure under harsh methanol reforming process. To investigate the crack resistance of the T i O 2 layer, the FESEM Images of the T i O 2 /monolith surface were compared with A l 2 O 3 /monolith surface as a common support for the SRM reaction [7,55,56] (Fig. 3 ). Accordingly, One of the defects that can be appointed to A l 2 O 3 as a common support is the cracked layer of it on the monolith surface, but the surface of the T i O 2 /monolith has advantage to be homogenous without any crack. Also, the effect of nature of support on adherence was investigated with 15 min. ultrasonic test. The obtained results indicated that the adherence of the Al2O3/monolith and TiO2/monolith samples are about 96% and 99%, respectively. These outcomes conformed the appropriate stability and adherence of T i O 2 on monolith surface. Wet impregnation of the prepared monolith/ T i O 2 support was achieved by the metal solutions. After drying, the produced salt layers were converted to the related metal oxide by calcination in 300–400 °C (except H 2 P t C l 6 which was directly converted to the Pt). The FESEM and AFM images of the T i O 2 film coated with above metal oxides are illustrated in Fig. 4 . The coated T i O 2 layer with ruthenium oxide is displayed in Fig. 4a, which indicates that the layer morphology and homogeneity were preserved after treatment with the metal precursor. This homogeneity and high adsorption of metal (see Table 1 ) on support was mainly related to the electrostatic interactions between the metal cation and hydroxyl group on the support. These interactions depend on the pH of the precursor solution and point zero charge (PZC) of the support. When pH of a precursor is upper than PZC, cation adsorption sites in the form of charged hydroxyl groups are generated on the surface of the support [57]. In the case of Ru(CH3COO)3 the pH of the precursor (pH: 9.5) is higher compared to the PZC of T i O 2 (PZC: 5–7 [57]) enhancing the electrostatic adsorption of the cations. The pH of the other precursors (Cu precursor pH:2.6 and Cu-Ni precursor pH:2.7) are lower than the PZC of the T i O 2 . Under these conditions, the electrostatic adsorption of the cations on the surface of the support is seriously diminished [58]. In the case of Cu and Cu-Ni precursors, the metal loading is decreased on the surface of the support by the low electrostatic adsorption of the cations on surface of T i O 2 . Therefore, the metal loading depends on pore volume of the support. In the case of Pt loading, hydrolysis of the H2PtCl6 in the impregnating solution will produce anion such as HPtCl6 −1, which is absorbed on the cationic charged surface of the T i O 2 . Consequently, in this sample the metal loading can be enhanced with electrostatic adsorption as well as solution pores filling. With regards to Fig. 4b, when the copper oxide was deposited on the T i O 2 film surface, large metal oxide particles were created in the pores and surface of the T i O 2 film. This fact can be interpreted by the melt infiltration process [59] and unsuitable electrostatic adsorption of metal. The melt infiltration process was observed for metal precursors with sufficiently different melt and decomposition temperatures. In this process, the melted precursors are sucked into the support pores by the capillary forces of the pores. The melting point of the Cu(NO3)2·3H2O is about 114.5 °C causing the migration of the melted salt into the pores of the T i O 2 film before calcination process. These migrations create large particles of CuO crystals in the T i O 2 pores, which can decrease the surface area, pore size, and porosity of the catalyst film and consequently reduce the catalyst efficiency. One possible route to solve this problem is the co-impregnation of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with another metal salt, which has a boiling point near to the copper nitrate melting point. In this situation, the vapor pressure of the low boiling component repels the capillary forces and prevents the migration. A considerable candidate for this matter is nickel nitrate, mainly because of its boiling point (136.7 °C) and its favorite interaction with titanium oxide.[60,61] Although, Ni does not have catalytic activity like Cu in the SRM reaction [62], its salt as co-impregnate can prevent the formation of those large particles. Giving the above reasons, the wet impregnation process of the T i O 2 /monolith was done in a 1:1 solution of Cu and Ni nitrate and was calcined at 300 °C. The AFM and FESEM images of this sample (Fig. 4c) show that the large copper oxide particles had been eliminated, while the morphology of the T i O 2 film were preserved. Fig. 5 a,b. shows the AFM images of the deposited Pt on the T i O 2 film. H 2 P t C l 6 is directly converted into Pt under thermal conditions (near 400 °C) [63]. In this conversion, the salt thermally decomposed to Pt with the oxidation of its chloride. The obtained AFM images indicate that large particles (about 1 μm size) are created in the pores and surface of the T i O 2 film. The melt infiltration effect is the supposed reason for this observation. An approach to overcome this problem is to use another platinum precursor with a higher melting point. H 2 P t ( O H ) 6 was chosen as the appropriate compound, which converted to PtO2 with losing four water molecule at about 500 °C [46]. The thermal behavior of H 2 P t ( O H ) 6 can decrease the melt infiltration, which is expected to reduce the catalyst particles size. Also the same as H2PtCl6, the existence of the Pt in form of anion such as HPt(OH)6 − in the precursor can enhance the electronic adsorption of metal on surface of the support. The AFM image of the prepared T i O 2 /PtO2 film with a H 2 P t ( O H ) 6 solution (pH:1.8) is shown in Fig. 5c, d. These images clearly indicated that the T i O 2 layer pattern has been preserved after this treatment and large Pt particles have not been formed in the pores and surface of the layer. Table 1 shows the percentage of the active metal in the catalyst samples. The wet impregnation (WT) time for Ru and Pt were reduced to decrease the loading of these expensive metals. The percentage of the active metal in the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith and Cu-Ni/ T i O 2 /monolith samples where kept similar to the Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith as reference sample, in order to accomplish an accurate comparison between them. Also, the Ru/ T i O 2 /monolith and Pt/ T i O 2 /monolith exhibited a similar metal loading near 5%. X-ray powder diffraction analysis was used for the characterization of the calcined T i O 2 /metal samples (see Fig. 6 ). The XRD pattern of synthesized T i O 2 nanoparticles clearly reveals the T i O 2 nanocrystals’ growth in anatase phase (JCPDS# 21–1272). These obtained results were confirmed by the far-infrared investigation, which displayed anatase peaks (see supporting information Fig. S6). These anatase phase and crystals structure have been preserved after calcination in all samples indicating the stability of the T i O 2 nanocrystals under calcination conditions. Generally, the anatase phase exhibits stronger metal support interaction [64] and higher catalytic activity compared to the rutile phase [65]. The XRD pattern of the Ru/ T i O 2 sample shows two peaks at 28.2° and 35.4°, indexed to the RuO2 rutile crystal phase, assigned to (1 1 0) and (1 0 1) planes (JCPDS 43–1027), respectively. The XRD pattern of the Cu/ T i O 2 sample indicates two sharp peaks at 35.7° and 39° assigned to CuO crystal (JCPDS 65–2309). These peaks disappeared after adding Ni to the Ni/Cu/ T i O 2 sample, which indicates that Ni co-impregnation prevented the formation of crystals. However, the FT-IR investigation confirmed the existence of NiO in the sample (see supporting information Fig. S6). The pattern of Pt/ T i O 2 sample does not display any peaks of the Pt or PtO2, because their very small crystal sizes make them X-ray-amorphous. This fact can be explained by the thermal behavior of H 2 P t ( O H ) 6 , which is partly dehydrated at 300 °C and makes an amorphous compound including PtO2.4H2O, PtO2.2H2O, and PtO2 [46]. The surface area and pore volume of T i O 2 , Cu/ T i O 2 , Cu-Ni/ T i O 2 , Pt/ T i O 2 and Ru/ T i O 2 samples were evaluated using their N2 physisorption isotherms acquired at 77 K. It has been seen in Fig. S7. that the isotherms of five samples are similar in containing a hysteresis loop between the relative pressure (P/P0) range of ∼0.4–0.9. This is indicative of capillary condensation in mesoporous. The sharpness of this step suggests narrow pore size distribution. It is recognized that this isotherm shape is related to the type-IV isotherm showing a noticeable hysteresis loop at high P/P0, confirming the presence of mesoporous within the sample. The H1 (uniform size and shape) type hysteresis loops generally correspond to the slit-like pores. A sharp rise in N2 uptake at relative pressures above 0.95 is due to the N2 condensation in the inter-particle pores. The BET data for the support and fresh catalyst are summarized in Table 1, indicating the maintenance of the T i O 2 mesoporous structures. Also, the table depicts the BJH pore size distribution of different T i O 2 /metal catalysts indicating reasonably narrow distribution in the range of 22–24 nm. Indeed, it was expected that the impregnation of the active metals led to reductions in the surface areas/pore volumes due to filling the surfaces/pores of supports by the metal catalysts. It is apparent from Table 1, that the bare support presents superior specific surface area which diminishes after metal (Cu, Cu-Ni, Pt, and Ru) addition. In addition, the total pore volume was decreased, while the pore size was increased. The smaller pores are blocked first, which results in an increased average pore size. Similar observations were reported by Panpranot et al. [66]. The interaction between the T i O 2 layer and a metal over-layer may crucially influence the metal’s properties and subsequently its performance as a catalyst [67]. Consequently, TPR investigation of the T i O 2 /metal samples can provide information about the interactions between the metal and T i O 2 support correlating to the catalytic activity in SRM reactions [68]. The TPR profiles of the prepared catalyst samples examined under identical operating conditions are shown in Fig. 7 . The Cu/ T i O 2 catalyst sample displays its main peak centred at 209 °C and a shoulder at about 150 °C, which was assigned to two CuO species with varying weak interactions [68]. The first peak (150 °C) can be attributed to the reduction of the Cu2+ ions located in the T i O 2 lattice (Cu2+ in the α state) [69]. These CuO species are obtained by wet impregnation process and have two-dimensional (2D) Cu structures [70]. The second peak can be interpreted by the creation of small three-dimensional islands with weak interaction [71] on the T i O 2 support. The TPR profile of the Cu-Ni/ T i O 2 catalyst sample shows three peaks located at 223, 245, as well as a broad peak at 325 °C. The first peak (223 °C) is similar to the observed peak for the Cu/ T i O 2 sample and is attributed to the small three-dimensional islands of CuO with weak metal-support interaction. The second peak is assigned to the conversion of NiO interacting with CuO to Ni species [72]. According to previous reports [73], the presence of Cu and Ni in Cu-Ni samples produces spill-over hydrogen, which significantly accelerates the nucleation of the Ni metal in these reduction conditions. The last peak can be attributed to the NiO reduction with a weak interaction with T i O 2 [39]. Both Ru/ T i O 2 and Pt/ T i O 2 TPR profiles illustrate a sharp peak below that, generally reported for the RuO2 and PtO2 bulks [74]. Interestingly, these observed lower reduction temperature for these metal oxides indicate that a moderate metal support interaction at these samples enhances the reduction process. The time-on-stream (TOS) behaviour of the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith and Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith catalysts were investigated to evaluate the catalyst stability over time (See Fig. 8 a). The observed results revealed that methanol conversion decreased about 4 and 6% after 36 h for the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith and Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith catalysts, respectively. Therefore, the designed catalyst structures showed appropriate stability over 36 h on-stream. In addition, the methanol conversion of the copper catalyst in the monolith and fixed bed reactor were investigated and compared (Fig. 8b). It must be noted that in this experiment the catalyst loading in the fixed bed reactor was more than the monolith (over 2 times). Therefore, a precise comparison between their conversions cannot be accomplished. The obtained results indicate that the assembled catalyst on the frame of the monolith micro structure displayed higher conversion compared to the fixed bed reactor. These results revealed an important advantage of the microstructure of the monolith, in which a lower amount of active metal in the monolith reactor exhibited more activity compared to the fixed bed. This outcome can be explained appropriate accessibility of catalyst and high mass transfer in monolith structures. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith and Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith samples (obtained after 36 h catalytic performance) were achieved to investigate the coke formation on catalyst structures (see supporting information Fig. S8). The Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith sample displayed a weight loss (16%) between 500–670 °C, which can be attributed to the coke burning process. This coke burning process for the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith sample was observed at 570–680 °C with 7% weight loss. These obtained outcomes indicated that the coke selectivity is 0.98 and 0.49% for Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith and Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith samples, respectively. As a result, the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith sample exhibited a resistance to coke formation compared to the Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith sample indicating that it is the beneficial of this catalyst system. In order to investigate the comparative performance of different metal catalysts (including Cu, Cu-Ni, Pt, and Ru), the methanol conversion, H2 production and CO selectivity of these catalysts were studied. The catalytic performance of the above catalysts and Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith (as a reference) in SRM reaction has been illustrated in Fig. 9 , presenting the effects of reaction temperature on methanol conversion and selectivity towards H2 and CO. Also, these obtained data were summarized in Table 2 and compared with the best reported data for conversion and selectivity. The methanol conversion was commonly raised in all samples by temperature showing a strong influence of this factor on the reaction (Fig. 9a). For instance, in the case of the Ru/ T i O 2 /monolith sample, the conversion was improved from 51.5% to about 98.9% by increasing the temperature from 150 to 300 °C. This fact can be attributed to the endothermic nature of the SRM reaction [39]. An obvious outcome of these results is the remarkable activity of the different metal catalysts on T i O 2 support showing about 90–99 % conversion compared with the Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith sample (81%). Furthermore, the obtained results indicated a high conversion result among the best reported in the literatures [11,75] (also see Table 2). Interestingly, even though the conversion is remarkable for all catalysts, the highest conversion was observed for the ruthenium catalyst (Ru: 99%). This remarkable fact is explained by the appropriate ruthenium interaction with support [76] (see TPR results) and the surface area (106 m2/g) of this catalyst. In the same way, the lower conversion of the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith catalyst could be attributed to the absence of noticeable metal-support interactions resulting in the lower copper catalyse surface area (84 m2/g). In the Cu-Ni/ T i O 2 /monolith catalyst sample, the catalyst surface area is successfully increased by the co-impregnation of Ni and Cu resulting in the considerable increase of the conversion (93%). As previously stated, the selectivity of the reaction toward the high H2 and low CO formation is a critical point in SRM reaction coupling with fuel cells. The selectivity toward H2 and CO for all catalysts is displayed in Fig. 9b, c. All metal/ T i O 2 /monolith catalysts (except Cu-Ni/ T i O 2 /monolith) showed lower selectivity toward CO rather than the Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith indicating another advantage of the T i O 2 support compared with the γ-Al2O3 support. High CO selectivity during the SRM reaction has been previously reported for Pt [77] and other VIII group metals [78]. Libuda et al. [79] reported that the CO selectivity in the Pt catalyst depend on the strength of the Pt-CO bond. They demonstrated that the strength bonding among the Pt and CO lead to hindrance of the CO desorption from the Pt surface while facilitating the reaction of CO with hydroxyl to form CO2. The Pt-CO bond is enhanced when a π-back bonding from the Pt to the CO orbitals is formed. The strength of this π-back bonding increases with the electron density in the metal. In case of Pt supported on T i O 2 , the electron of the Ti+3 in the T i O 2 defects can be transferred to the group VIII noble metals [41] resulting in negatively charged metals, which can enhance the π-backbonding. This interaction between metal and support had been observed in the TPR result, which pushed the H2 consumption peak to lower temperatures. In the same way, the suitable selectivity of the Ru/ T i O 2 /monolith (5.4%) can be interpreted with a similar Ru and T i O 2 intraction. Although, the conversion of the Cu-Ni/TiO2/monolith catalyst is higher than Cu/TiO2/monolith, its CO selectivity is lower than the latter catalyst. The main reason for this result is the tendency of the Ni (with low metal support interaction) to selectively produce CO [78]. Recently, Deshmane et al. [62] reported a high CO selectivity (over 90%) for Ni on MCM-41 support (see Table 2). Further investigation of the CO selectivity indicated that the selectivity increased by raising the temperature, which was achieved by the endothermic behavior of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (3)). As a consequence, running the SRM reaction under low temperature condition has an advantage of appropriate CO selectivity. The hydrogen selectivity of the catalyst samples is displayed in Fig. 9c. All catalyst samples presented a high selectivity toward hydrogen (90–98%). Furthermore, the selectivity rose for the Cu/ T i O 2 /monolith catalyst (90%) compared to the Cu/γ-Al2O3/monolith (82%), which indicates another advantage of the T i O 2 in this process. These results are significant since the most important object of the methanol reforming reaction is hydrogen generation. The catalysts with the T i O 2 support illustrate a high conversion at 225 °C (above 80%). Furthermore, in this low temperature condition, a suitable selectivity toward the hydrogen and CO are acquired (see Table 2). Lowering the temperature saves the energy in SRM process, which is very important in fuel cell application. As a matter of fact, using the SRM reaction is clearly limited in fuel cell applications, as large amounts of energy must be supplied for the procedure to meet the essential methanol conversion [80]. These obtained results indicated that the designed catalyst structures can efficiently operate in low temperature condition with superb advantages. As pointed out by these outcomes, the SRM reaction can be performed by Ru/ T i O 2 /monolith catalyst in low-temperature conditions with the best results, which is related to the specific interaction between Ru and T i O 2 [76]. Although, the economically viable property and the activity of the copper-nickel catalyst makes it a considerable alternative for the ruthenium catalyst. 4 Conclusions A catalyst support was designed by coupling the microstructure frame (monolith) with nanostructure support ( T i O 2 nanoparticles). The monolith structure significantly increased the mass transfer of the substrates and products in the reactor. Coupling this excellent mass transfer with the appropriate physical properties of nanostructure T i O 2 film (such as suitable surface area, porosity, pore size, and stability) presented superb results in the SRM process. The obtained results show that the designed support/catalyst structure has a great influence on methanol conversion and products selectivity in this process. Among all of the examined metal catalysts, the ruthenium catalyst presented the highest conversion and selectivity for this process. However, the economically viable property of the copper-nickel catalyst makes it an excellent alternative for the ruthenium catalyst. These pronounced conversion and selectivity for the catalysts can be attributed to the metal-support interaction effects controlling the activity and dispersion of metal particles on the T i O 2 support. With this intention, we recommended the monolith/ T i O 2 as a great support for the Cu, Cu-Ni, Ru, and Pt catalyst in the methanol reforming reaction. coredata.dc:description: A comprehensive investigation on the steam reforming of methanol (SRM) process using a microstructure monolith in conjunction with a synthesized nanostructure of TiO2 is presented. The surface of the designed monolith/TiO2 structure was coated with copper, copper/nickel, ruthenium, and platinum as the catalyst. The prepared catalysts were then characterized with FE-SEM, AFM, BET surface area measurement, FT-IR, far-infrared, temperature programmed reduction (TPR), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The obtained results show that in this process, the designed Monolith/TiO2 structure has a remarkable impact on methanol conversion (99%) and carbon monoxide selectivity (5%). These results are interpreted by the high surface area and superb mass transfer in this micro/nano engineered structure. These results also indicated that the catalyst activity and dispersion are influenced by the metal-support interaction, which is more pronounced in the TiO2 supports. The ruthenium catalyst presented the highest conversion and selectivity for this process. However, the economically viable property of the Cu-Ni catalyst supposes it as an alternative for the noble ruthenium catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Highly porous monolith/TiO2 supported Cu, Cu-Ni, Ru, and Pt catalysts in methanol steam reforming process for H2 generation
